This meeting is scheduled to discuss: 161 Front Street - Flood Barrier Mitigation Review Details for meeting are as follows: Monday, March 28, 2016 Time: 1:00 PM Location: 59 Maiden Lane (37th Floor), Large Conference Room *NOTE: All projects must come  prepared to the meetings with detailed drawings and outline of the project. Details should depict measurements, sidewalk use, roadway use, and the actual roadway that is being worked on including cross street, barrier, flagger, materials and equipment proposed  to use at the site. A knowledgeable person of the project must make the presentation. If you are not prepared, the meeting will immediately be cancelled and rescheduled for a later date. An Interim Flood Protection Measures (IFPM) system is located in the roadway and/or sidewalk on this location. IFPMs are managed by NYC Emergency Management (NYCEM). IFPMs include permanent pre-installed or just-in-time components that are installed only in the event of an imminent coastal storm emergency, or for planned system testing purposes. Both component types may be located at grade and/or above grade. Prior to mobilizing, Permittees must contact NYCEM at IFPM@oem.nyc.gov for further instructions. If a coastal storm emergency develops after approved work starts, permittees shall follow any directives from NYCEM to shut down work, backfill excavations and remove or relocate equipment and materials within 24 hours if the work impedes IFPM installation. Permittee is responsible for restoration, replacement, and/or reconstruction of damaged NYCEM flood protection assets impacted by the Permittee, see: https://on.nyc.gov/381cQuV

The City provides assistance to businesses that suffer physical damage or business interruption as a result of fires, floods, ruptured water mains, building collapses or explosions, power outages and terrorist attacks.

Staff from the NYC Business Acceleration-Emergency Response Unit may be sent directly to the site to help the business owner.

You can report a construction or excavation project that causes improper grade changes. A change in a property's grade, slope, or level can cause flooding to neighboring properties and change the flow of water above ground.

The City accepts reports of damaged or dirty automatic public toilets. Problems may include broken glass, flooding, graffiti, broken or poor lighting, structural damage, lack of supplies, or operating issues.

The City also accepts requests for the placement of new automatic public toilets.

A private company installs and maintains automatic public toilets based on agreements with the City. The City reports complaints to the contractor and monitors the contractor's work. The City works closely with local community boards and other parties to identify new sites for automatic public toilets. Toilets can only be placed in areas that meet specific structural requirements, so land surveys are an important part of the selection process.

Flood insurance is required if you live in the FEMA defined floodplain and have a federally-backed mortgage. Flood insurance is not included in regular homeowners insurance, but anyone can purchase flood insurance, whether or not their homes were affected by Hurricane Sandy or are located in the FEMA 100-year floodplain.
The City provides information on flood zone designations for specific properties.

New flood insurance policy rates will take effect April 1, 2015. Primary residences will see a renewal increase of 18% of the current premium. If your home was substantially damaged in Superstorms Sandy or Irene, the policy renewal could increase by up to 25%. Second residences and businesses will see a policy renewal increase of up to 25%.

Residential and business owners will also pay a new surcharge called the 'Homeowner Flood Insurance Affordability Act of 2014 (HFIAA).' The surcharge for primary residences is $25 and secondary residences and businesses will be charged $250. You will automatically be billed $250, the HFIAA second-home rate. If your residence is your primary home, your insurance agent will send you a notice to submit proof to verify your primary residence. You must submit verification of primary residence to your insurance agent within 30 days from the date of the notice. If you do not submit verification in this timeframe, you will have to pay the $250 rate.

To receive the $25 HFIAA surcharge rate, you must submit ONE of the following proofs of primary residence:

  • Driver's license
  • Automobile registration
  • Proof of insurance for a vehicle
  • Voter registration
  • Documents showing where your children attend school
  • Homestead Tax Credit Form for Primary Residence

You can get more information and connect to housing counseling and legal services online or by calling (646)-786-0888.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has updated their Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRMs) to identify areas that are at risk of flooding. These maps are tied to the City’s Building Code, which establishes safe construction standards for building in the floodplain. Property owners can use these maps to determine their flood insurance requirements. They can also determine if their structure is in the floodplain and look up the specific preliminary base flood elevation and flood zone by address.

FEMA will have a Technical Appeals Period for the FIRMs. This will begin on March 31, 2015 and will last for 90 days. An appeal must be based on scientific and technical issues with FEMA methodology and mapping. An appeal can object to the new or modified Base Flood Elevations (BFEs), floodplain boundaries or flood zone designations on the updated Flood Insurance Rate Maps. Because there is additional data required to submit an appeal, appeals can be submitted online or by mail to:

Mayor's Office of Recovery and Resiliency
c/o Flood Map Appeals
253 Broadway, 10th Floor
New York, NY 10007

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has sent letters to New York City residents living in or near the FEMA Preliminary Flood Insurance Rate Map flood zones. The letter advises residents to understand the flood risk and to purchase flood insurance if necessary.

If you have received a letter, you should first check whether or not you are in a flood zone. 

If you are not in a flood zone, you are not required to buy flood insurance. You can still may purchase flood insurance if you prefer.

If you are in a flood zone, you can get more information on flood insurance requirements by calling (877) FEMA-MAP (877-336-2627), or by vising the FloodHelpNY website.

No one is allowed to enter structures or buildings that have active, limited, or full preemptory vacate orders in effect. If a person is currently on the premises, you should call 911.

Vacate orders are issued to ensure public safety from damaged buildings, illegal or unsafe conditions, or dangerous conditions that may exist on or near the property. If you have seen people on the premises but they are no longer there, you may file a report with the City. Violations are issued when appropriate.

The amount of time a vacate order is in effect depends on the severity of the problem and how soon an unsafe condition is corrected. Details are provided on placard stickers posted on the premises by personnel from the Department of Buildings (DOB) and other agencies. Depending on the color of the placard sticker, the entire building or a specified portion of the building structure may no longer be accessible.

Once posted on the premises, placard stickers must remain on the premises until you are notified by the DOB.

In the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, DOB is conducting inspections of structures affected by the storm. Inspection placard stickers have been placed on inspected properties.

The placard sticker colors and what they mean:

•  Green - No restriction: No apparent structural hazard was observed. You are not restricted from entering and re-occupying your building. The Green sticker must remain on your premises until you are notified by the Department of Buildings.

•  Yellow - Restricted use: Property is damaged. Entry limitations are specified on each posting. You must have an architect or engineer evaluate for structural damage. If you only had flooding, you must hire a New York City licensed electrician or plumber to perform work. The Yellow sticker must remain on your premises until you are notified by the Department of Buildings.

•  Red - Unsafe: Property is seriously damaged and is unsafe to enter or occupy. A red tag does not mean your home will be demolished. Red tagged property indicates that there is some form of hazard that prohibits re-entry or re-occupancy, such as a structural issue. You must have an architect or engineer evaluate. The Red sticker must remain on your premises until you are notified by the Department of Buildings.

For additional information, you should contact DOB using the phone number provided on the placard sticker, or by calling the phone number provided for your borough.

• Staten Island (only): (212) 566-3227
• Staten Island, Queens: (212) 566-3587
• Staten Island,Bronx, Manhattan, and Brooklyn: (212) 566-3625

The City provides Ready New York guides for information about how to prepare for emergencies in New York City. The guides also contain information about how to put together a Go Bag and an emergency supply kit.:

Select guides are available in English, Spanish, Arabic, Bengali, Chinese, Haitian Creole, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Russian, Urdu, and Yiddish, as well as others. A pocket guide, quick reference card, or audio version for the hard of hearing is also available. In addition to the general Ready New York Guide, there are specialized guides for:

  • Creating an Emergency Plan
  • Emergency preparedness
  • Pocket-Sized Emergency Preparedness
  • Businesses
  • Kids
  • Seniors and people with disabilities
  • Pets
  • Pandemic flu
  • Flooding situations
  • Hurricanes
  • Staying healthy in the summer heat

If you need more than 50 copies of a Ready New York Guide, send a request by mail to:

Ready New York Program
New York City Emergency Management
165 Cadman Plaza East
Brooklyn, NY 11201

To request hard copies, you can send an email to readyny@oem.nyc.gov.

An 11 minute video on emergency preparedness is also available.
You can report water flooding or ponding on a street or highway. You can also report a manhole that is overflowing with water or sewage.

The Interim Flood Protection Measures Program is designed to protect critical facilities, infrastructure, and low-lying areas throughout the City from flooding caused by a hurricane.

You can report damage to your property caused by a hurricane or flooding online, through the Damage Assessment Tool. The information collected will be used to assess the extent of the damage, allocate resources, and seek disaster assistance.

For more information, you can send an email to floodprotection@oem.nyc.gov or call the Interim Flood Protection Measures Program at (718) 422-4601.

You can report a sewer backup in a building, even if the condition has cleared and the water is gone. You can also learn about cleaning up after a flood or report flooding in your basement due to heavy rainfall or large snow melt.

You can report a sewer backup, even if the condition has cleared and the water is gone. You can also learn about cleaning up after a flood or report flooding in your basement due to heavy rainfall or large snow melt.

You can also report a manhole that is overflowing with water or sewage.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has sent letters to New York City residents living in or near the FEMA Preliminary Flood Insurance Rate Map flood zones. The letter advises residents to understand the flood risk and to purchase flood insurance if necessary.

If you have received a letter, you should first check whether or not you are in a flood zone. 

If you are not in a flood zone, you are not required to buy flood insurance. You can still may purchase flood insurance if you prefer.

If you are in a flood zone, you can get more information on flood insurance requirements by calling (877) FEMA-MAP (877-336-2627), or by vising the FloodHelpNY website.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has updated their Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRMs) to identify areas that are at risk of flooding. These maps are tied to the City’s Building Code, which establishes safe construction standards for building in the floodplain. Property owners can use these maps to determine their flood insurance requirements. They can also determine if their structure is in the floodplain and look up the specific preliminary base flood elevation and flood zone by address.

FEMA will have a Technical Appeals Period for the FIRMs. This will begin on March 31, 2015 and will last for 90 days. An appeal must be based on scientific and technical issues with FEMA methodology and mapping. An appeal can object to the new or modified Base Flood Elevations (BFEs), floodplain boundaries or flood zone designations on the updated Flood Insurance Rate Maps. Because there is additional data required to submit an appeal, appeals can be submitted online or by mail to:

Mayor's Office of Recovery and Resiliency
c/o Flood Map Appeals
253 Broadway, 10th Floor
New York, NY 10007

No one is allowed to enter structures or buildings that have active, limited, or full preemptory vacate orders in effect. If a person is currently on the premises, you should call 911.

Vacate orders are issued to ensure public safety from damaged buildings, illegal or unsafe conditions, or dangerous conditions that may exist on or near the property. If you have seen people on the premises but they are no longer there, you may file a report with the City. Violations are issued when appropriate.

The amount of time a vacate order is in effect depends on the severity of the problem and how soon an unsafe condition is corrected. Details are provided on placard stickers posted on the premises by personnel from the Department of Buildings (DOB) and other agencies. Depending on the color of the placard sticker, the entire building or a specified portion of the building structure may no longer be accessible.

Once posted on the premises, placard stickers must remain on the premises until you are notified by the DOB.

In the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, DOB is conducting inspections of structures affected by the storm. Inspection placard stickers have been placed on inspected properties.

The placard sticker colors and what they mean:

•  Green - No restriction: No apparent structural hazard was observed. You are not restricted from entering and re-occupying your building. The Green sticker must remain on your premises until you are notified by the Department of Buildings.

•  Yellow - Restricted use: Property is damaged. Entry limitations are specified on each posting. You must have an architect or engineer evaluate for structural damage. If you only had flooding, you must hire a New York City licensed electrician or plumber to perform work. The Yellow sticker must remain on your premises until you are notified by the Department of Buildings.

•  Red - Unsafe: Property is seriously damaged and is unsafe to enter or occupy. A red tag does not mean your home will be demolished. Red tagged property indicates that there is some form of hazard that prohibits re-entry or re-occupancy, such as a structural issue. You must have an architect or engineer evaluate. The Red sticker must remain on your premises until you are notified by the Department of Buildings.

For additional information, you should contact DOB using the phone number provided on the placard sticker, or by calling the phone number provided for your borough.

• Staten Island (only): (212) 566-3227
• Staten Island, Queens: (212) 566-3587
• Staten Island,Bronx, Manhattan, and Brooklyn: (212) 566-3625
You can report water flooding on a street or highway. You can also report a manhole that is overflowing with water or sewage.

The Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) is coordinating a public education campaign to encourage New Yorkers to 'Trash It. Don't Flush It.'

When cooking grease, wipes, and other items get flushed down drains or toilets, they can clog sewer pipes. Even items that are labeled 'flushable' may not clear pipes or break down in the sewer system or a wastewater treatment plant. This mix of personal hygiene products and grease can create 'fatbergs' in our sewers and can lead to more flooding, sewer backups, damage to pipes and treatment plants, and high repair costs.

The Interim Flood Protection Measures Program is designed to protect critical facilities, infrastructure, and low-lying areas throughout the City from flooding caused by a hurricane.

You can report damage to your property caused by a hurricane or flooding online, through the Damage Assessment Tool. The information collected will be used to assess the extent of the damage, allocate resources, and seek disaster assistance.

For more information, send an email to floodprotection@oem.nyc.gov.

Owners of homes and businesses can report damage to their buildings or property caused by a recent storm. If you are renting property in the affected areas and have property damage, you can submit your damage report to the City. Your report will be used for tracking and reporting purposes only.

Protection against property loss due to flooding is not covered under a homeowner's insurance policy. You must have purchased separate flood insurance in order to be covered.

Conditions conducive to the existence of pests in that 1 reach-down freezer chest was observed encrusted with an unknown sticky particles in the compressor compartment of reach-down freezer chest in the basement food prep area. Cement/concrete flood observed littered with old food particles behind reach-down freezer chest. Crevices was observed in the wall tile and concrete wall behind 1-door reach-in mini-refrigerator in the basement food storage area. Live roaches were observed in the basement. NYCHC 81.23(a)  Please note that the violation you have been issued for having conditions conducive the existence of pests is separate and distinct from the violation you have been issued for having pests and both may be sustained by the Hearings Division.  See DOHMH v. Harissa LLC, Dkt 0879213F0, Appeal Decision Oct. 8, 2013 at 1 and DOHMH v. Just Lorraine's Place, LLC Dkt 2748012F1, Appeal Decision Apr. 9, 2013 at 4. available on nyls.edu/cityadmin.

Evidence of mouse activity present in that 33 fresh mice excreta observed in the following areas: 4 observed on floor next to 1-door reach-in refrigerator in 2nd floor, 2 observed along floor wall junction outside liquor storage room in 2nd floor, 23 observed on flood under liquor storage shelf in 2nd floor and 2 observed on wooden ledge in bar and 2 observed on floor in bar. Corrective action: Operator instructed to implement proper pest control measures by removing harborage conditions, such as standing water, closing all entry ways and holes, storing food in vermin proof containers, eliminating breeding conditions, improve overall sanitary conditions, and provide proper extermination, if necessary.  All contaminated area and equipment are to be washed, rinsed, and sanitized.NYCHC 81.23(a)

Evidence of mouse activity present in that 35 fresh mice excreta observed in establishment ( 28 fresh mice excreta observed on flood under food storage shelf in basement and  7 fresh mice excreta observed on floor behind  one door reach-down freezer (in-use) in basement at the time of inspection). Corrective action: Operator instructed to implement proper pest control measures by removing harborage conditions, such as standing water, closing all entry ways and holes, storing food in vermin proof containers, eliminating breeding conditions, improve overall sanitary conditions, and provide proper extermination, if necessary.  All contaminated area and equipment are to be washed, rinsed, and sanitized..NYCHC 81.23(a)

Facility conditions conducive to the existence of pest life observed in that office ceiling in basement observed fallen down and dripping with water. Operator stated that ceiling had collapsed and upstiars kitchen was leaking into office causing flooding. Excessive amount of grease and old food debris observed underneath stoves and roaster in basement kitchen. NYCHC 81.23(a)

Flooring improperly constructed or maintained in that cement/concrete floor observed with heavy accumulation of standing water due to flooding from unknown source in wine storage room and kitchen in basement. NYCHC 81.17(e) (1)

Food contact surface unclean in that one regularly used can opener blade observed encrusted with old food and not being cleaned & sanitized after use noted in a metal container on flood prep table in kitchen. Said item was observed being stored for usage when needed. NYCHC 81.27(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid in that stagnant, brown, foul smelling water with feces was observed contaminating the entire basement food storage area. Freezer chests, walk-in refrigerator and canned goods are located in this area. The entire floor is flooded with 1 to 2 inches of water. Corrective action: Food service establishment closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because sewage-contaminated area could not be properly cleaned. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that an accumulation of liquid waste approximately 2 inches deep was observed contaminating the entire food and supply storage area in the basement. The liquid waste was observed draining into and flooding the walk-in refrigerator (holding food) and the basement storage area, from the backyard. The operator stated a clogged drain from the backyard affected adequate draining of water from the rain, which subsequently drained into the basement.. Corrective action: Food service establishment closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because reason for sewage failure was not corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that liquid waste (brown and greasy) from grease trap was observed contaminating food prep area in basement. Said liquid waste (approximately 8 inches in length and 3 inches in depth) was observed on floor in meter room at the time of inspection. As per manager, said food prep area was flooded one day prior. An employee was observed mopping said contaminated area at the time of inspection.Water marks were observed on food items that were stored directly on floor in basement food prep area at the time of inspection. Corrective action: All food was removed from the area.  Contaminated food was rendered inedible and discarded.  Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that liquid waste was observed contaminating the basement where food storage, food preparation, and warewashing was observed. At time of inspection odorless liquid was observed in the basement along the walls and pooling near the sump pump behind the 3-compartment sink. As per the owner's statement water has been seeping in from the ground for a few days and is mopped up regularly. The room that leads to the boiler room was observed completely flooded with liquid approximately three quarters of an inch deep. Corrective action: Food Service Establishment voluntarily closed and agreed not to reopen until issue is corrected, everything is sanitized, and FSE must be granted permission to reopen by NYC DOHMH. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that liquid waste water from the kitchen was observed with the entire ceiling fallen in with a bursted pipe which caused a flood which was observed contaminating the equipment storage in the basement. Said flooded water was observed cloudy, murky grey colored and creating a strong pungent sewer smell. In the basement was observed paper goods storage, grease drums. Corrective action: All food was removed from the area.  Contaminated food was rendered inedible and discarded.  Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that the rear food prep area in basement was observed contaminated by brown and greasy waste water that was flowing directly from clogged grease trap in grease trap room directly into said prep area. Said waste water was observed contaminating said prep area where food preparation and storage was observed during inspection. At the time of the inspection, said grease trap was observed leaking directly onto floor when 3-compartment sink in kitchen is turned on. As per operator, said location was observed flooded the night before the inspection. Corrective action: Operator was instructed to contact licensed plumber to fix raw sewage failure. Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food found contaminated in that 4 cases of assorted Snapple beverages on metal storage shelf, two containers with cooked tomato sauce stored directly on floor in walk-in refrigerator, a  carton of lettuce in walk-in refrigerator, a 40 pound box of raw chicken wings on a rolling cart in walk-in refrigerator were all observed to be contaminated by contact with liquid waste murky water that  flooded  entire basement food storage area. Corrective action: Foods were rendered inedible and discarded by food worker. NYCHC 81.07(a)

Food found contaminated in that approximately 10 pound(s) of peeled plantain(s), approximately 15 pounds of chopped sweet potatoes, and approximately 15 pounds of uncooked onions observed to be contaminated by direct contact with raw sewage/ waste water on lower metal shelf inside walk-in refrigerator in basement. Said food item came into contact with dirty waste water when basement was completely flooded by approximately 6 inches of waste water prior to inspection. Corrective action: Food was rendered inedible and discarded by food worker. NYCHC 81.07(a)

Food preparation area, food storage area or other area used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that liquid sewage water leaking profusely from the ceiling above the delivery staircase leading to the outside was observed contaminating the food storage area in the basement. liquid waste was observed flooding the floor of the food/paper goods storage area containing single use items for customer use and an assortment of condiments. Walk-in refrigerator is also located in the basement approximately 20 feet away from where the leakage is occurring. Corrective action: Operator closed down the FSE and called a licensed plumber. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Handwash facility inadequate in that bar handwash sink/3-compartment sink, male and female employee/patron toilet facility handwash sink and a non-used kitchen hand wash sink observed without hot running water, at the time of inspection. Two male patrons noted being served alcoholic beverages at bar. Due to severe hurricane/flood conditions the past two days the gas-fired hot water heater has been inoperable, as per operator's statement. NYCHC 81.29(c)

Harborage or conditions conducive to rodents, insects or other pests exist in that 1/2'' gap which was leading to outside observed between door and door frame at front entrance in customer ordering area. Old flood particles and grease observed on floor under steamers and roast oven in kitchen. Floor observed wet and greasy throughout kitchen. NYCHC 81.23(a) Please note that the violation you have been issued for having conditions conducive the existence of pests is separate and distinct from the violation you have been issued for having pests and both may be sustained by the Hearings Division. See DOHMH v. Harissa LLC, Dkt 0879213F0, Appeal Decision Oct. 8, 2013 at 1 and DOHMH v. Just Lorraine's Place, LLC Dkt 2748012F1, Appeal Decision Apr. 9, 2013 at 4. available on nyls.edu/cityadmin.

Liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system so as to prevent contamination of the premises and its contents in that a large amount of murky water measuring approximately 1 inch deep and covering entire concrete floor of meter room and dry good storage room was observed  in basement. Operator stated that said water was coming from a broken pipe but was unable to locate said pipe. Food workers were observed walking through flooded area to get to basement kitchen and bring food upstairs without any other possible path to do so. No floor drains were observed in flooded area. .  NYCHC 81.20(b)

Liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system so as to prevent contamination of the premises and its contents in that connecting pipe from indirect waste line, observed draining water directly onto floor at 2 compartment sink in basement. Funnel of indirect drain was observed overflowing and flooding the floor next to said sink.  NYCHC 81.20(b)

Liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system so as to prevent contamination of the premises and its contents in that rain waste water was dripping from the ciling tiles in the kitchen. As per FPC Holder statement said water came from the excess rain that fell and flooded the air conditioning unit.  NYCHC 81.20(b)

Liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system so as to prevent contamination of the premises and its contents in that waste water observed backing up from floor drain in front of  2nd kitchen flooding the main bowl cart .  NYCHC 81.20(b)

Mouse activity present in that approximately 30 mouse excreta observed on floor behind gas hot water heater in basement, 15 mouse excreta observed on paper goods storage shelf in basement and 8 mouse excreta observed on flood in AC room in kitchen . Corrective action: Operator instructed to implement proper pest control measures by removing harborage conditions, such as standing water, closing all entry ways and holes, storing food in vermin proof containers, eliminating breeding conditions, improve overall sanitary conditions, and provide proper extermination, if necessary.  All contaminated area and equipment are to be washed, rinsed, and sanitized..NYCHC 81.23(a)

No facilities to wash, rinse and sanitize equipment, utensils and tableware provided in that Dishwasher and 2-compartment sink not available for ceramic and glassware washing operation. No hot water observed running in any faucets/dashwasher throughout the establishment at time of inspection. Establishment are unable to properly wash, rinse and sanitize china/glass ware without adequate hot running water. Owner informed me that there was no hot running water throughout the day and water boiler was faulty due to  water flood in the boiler room in next door basement affecting establishment hot water heater. NYCHC 81.29(a)
Non-food contact surface(s) or non food contact equipment not properly maintained in that concrete floor was observed flooded in basement non food storage area. NYCHC 81.17(e)(3)

Potable water system not protected from backflow in that air gap not provided on spray arms on 3-compartment sink in basement. The said spray arm was observed inside the sink not a minimum of 1'' above the flood rim of the sink. Corrective action: Operator was instructed to have the spray arm fixed at minimum of 1'' above the flood rim of the sink. NYCHC 81.20(a)

Potentially hazardous cold food, other than processed fish, not held at or below 41ï¿½F  (5ï¿½C) in that approximately 8 pound(s) of raw   beef hamburger patties noted being held for customer service  registered at 45ï¿½F in 2-door lowboy refrigerator in kitchen . Food has been in said location for 2.5 hour(s), as per operator's statement. Sewage and liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system so as to prevent contamination of the premises and its contents in that indirect waste line observed leaking directly into open and uncovered grease trap under three compartment sink. Sewage disposal system improperly constructed or operated in that liquid waste observed coming out from floor drain in the middle of the room in warewashing area when 2-compartment sink and chemical dishwasher is in use. Corrective action: Food service establishment closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because sewage disposal system could not be properly operated. NYCHC 81.20(b) and (c )

Sewage disposal system not provided, improperly constructed or not operating adequately in that stagnant cloudy liquid waste water due to sewage back up from floor drain basement non-food storage area observed measuring approximately 1 inch deep in the tiled floor of the basement main area where old equipment is stored and the concrete floor of the garbage storage area of basement. Basement was flooded from sewage back up coming from the drain in the middle of the main area of the basement 1 hour prior to inspection, as per operator's statement. Corrective action: Food service establishment was closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because the reason for sewage failure was not corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Sewage/liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system in that waste observed contaminating basement food prep/storage area. A licensed plumber corrected the problem and said area was cleaned and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Sewage/liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system in that waste observed contaminating beneath 3-compartment sink and handwash sink in kitchen. Hot water noted turned off at all sinks at time of inspection. Hot water is turned off in order to prevent flooding of area, as per operator. Corrective action: Food service establishment closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because reason for sewage failure was not corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Toilet facilities not provided for employees in that out of order in the employee restroom. Toilet was observed over flooded and would not flush. Conditions conducive to the existence of pests in that an approximately 1 inch by 3 inches hole was observed in the ceiling leading to an unknown space around an electrical pipe above reach-down freezer chest in the basement food storage area. NYCHC 81.23(a)  Please note that the violation you have been issued for having conditions conducive the existence of pests is separate and distinct from the violation you have been issued for having pests and both may be sustained by the Hearings Division.  See DOHMH v. Harissa LLC, Dkt 0879213F0, Appeal Decision Oct. 8, 2013 at 1 and DOHMH v. Just Lorraine's Place, LLC Dkt 2748012F1, Appeal Decision Apr. 9, 2013 at 4. available on nyls.edu/cityadmin.

Enclosed service area not provided for the cleaning and servicing of mobile food units Service room was observed dry and using as storage of hand trucks , floor dry, no servicing of pushcarts found, besides all pushcart storage area observed flooded with water. NYCHC 89.27 (c)

Evidence of mouse activity present in that (29) fresh mice excreta observed (5) observed scattered on floor inside miscellaneous storage closet in seating area on 1st floor, (3) observed on floor underneath bar counter on 1st floor, (8) observed scattered along wooden ledge underneath bar counter on 3rd floor, (7) observed along floor-wall junction next to mobile carts in basement and (6) observed on flood behind desk inside office in basement. Corrective action: Operator instructed to implement proper pest control measures by removing harborage conditions, such as standing water, closing all entry ways and holes, storing food in vermin proof containers, eliminating breeding conditions, improve overall sanitary conditions, and provide proper extermination, if necessary.  All contaminated area and equipment are to be washed, rinsed, and sanitized.NYCHC 81.23(a)

Evidence of mouse activity present in that 59 fresh mice excreta were observed in the following areas: 6 observed on flood under food storage shelves in basement rear food storage room; 8 observed on floor under equipment storage shelves in basement equipment storage room; 18 observed under food prep table and 13 observed on floor next to door to backyard in basement kitchen; 8 observed on floor next to door to backyard in first floor kitchen; and 6 observed behind trash bin in customer seating area  . Corrective action: PIC instructed to implement proper pest control measures.  Remove harborage conditions such as standing water, close all entry ways and holes, store food in vermin proof containers, eliminate breeding conditions and improve overall sanitary conditions.NYCHC 81.23(a)

Facility conditions conducive to the existence of pest life observed in that accumulation of grease/ chunks of grease observed on underside of the front panels of wok stoves in kitchen. Mechanical compartment under deep fryer was observed with grease in kitchen. Scattered old food particles observed on floor at wall and flood junction under wok stoves and deep fryer in kitchen . NYCHC 81.23(a)

Facility conditions conducive to the existence of pest life observed in that accumulation of standing water on floor due to flooding as per FPC Holder's statement observed under four reach-in refrigerators/freezers along wall leading to rear food prep area. NYCHC 81.23(a)
Flooring improperly constructed or maintained in that basement floor observed flooded with approximately 1" of rain water at time of inspection. NYCHC 81.21(e)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that cloudy water waterof unknown origin observed actively flowing from the ceiling in and out walk-in keg refrigerator, flooding the unit and the rest of the basement with an extending waste. That extending waste water approximately 2-inch in depth was observed contaminating the basement used for the beer kegs and sodas storage area. Corrective action: Food service establishment closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because reason for sewage failure was not corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food preparation area, food storage area or other area used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that clear rainwater in the entire basement floor (approximately 3 inch depth) leaking from roof was observed contaminating entire floor. Said area was flooded 20 minutes prior to inspection, as per FPC holder MUSHTAG BALMACOON. Contaminating water observed all over the floor throughout the basement employee's restroom, single service storage area, ice machine, liquor storage room that clearly contaminating the FSE.  Corrective action: Reason for sewage failure was corrected. Operator instructed to get a professional cleaning to wash, rinse, and sanitize the contaminated area. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Hand washing facility not provided in establishmentwhere various foods (chicken, rice, beans, etc) is being prepared and/or served. Upon arrival, no running water was observed throughout establishment. Gas hot water heater observed overflowing with water and flooding the basement. Main water line was shut off by operator to stop flooding. According to operator, flooding has been consistent for approximately 2 weeks.  NYCHC 81.29(c)

Harborage or conditions conducive to rodents, insects or other pests exist in that (1) standing, murky water approximately 4 inches deep was observed flooding the basement floor adjacent to areas where live fruit flies were observed swarming and (2) 2 bags of food waste were observed being stored on the floor and not in tightly covered waste receptacles in the rear of the kitchen where live fruit flies were observed. Liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system so as to prevent contamination of the premises and its contents in that clear odorless liquid waste was observed gushing/leaking out of an approximately 1 inch in diameter hole in the wall behind the water heaters in the basement. NYCHC 81.21 (e). Flooring not properly maintained or constructed in that open garden hose observed flooding basement with large amounts of water. Flooring noted with approximately 3 inches of water flooding middle and rear areas of basement. Basement noted used for chemical storage and hot water heaters noted in rear area of basement. Operator was instructed to contact the proper professionals to correct said issue immediately.

Regulation: 48.15(a)(15) Exits from areas with 15 or more persons or not readily visible shall be identified by lighted signs and directional signs as required Violation: At the time of inspection/visit the cited regulation was observed not in compliance in that emergency egress flood lights and signs on basement level, second and thrid floor level stairwells and hallways noted inoperable. Violation Exists in Office OFFICE Floor 1

Sewage disposal system improperly constructed or operated in that raw sewage/dirty waste water observed bubbling up/spewing from floor drain in basement food storage area at time of inspection. Said basement was observed completely flooded by approximately 6 inches in depth of dirty waste water. Walk-in refrigerator filled with food items observed flooded by approximately 6 inches in depth of waste water at time of inspection. Said basement was flooded one day prior to inspection, as per operator statement. Operator observed pumping water from basement to sidewalk at time of inspection. Establishment observed with customers eating on first floor, and food items from basement were observed being transported from flooded basement to first floor kitchen at time of inspection. As per operator statement, main building waste pipe broke or clogged up yesterday, thus flooding basement of said establishment and adjacent deli sharing same building.. Corrective action: Food service establishment

Sewage disposal system not provided, improper, inadequate or unapproved in that liquid waste water was observed backing up from the sewer ejector pump directly onto the floor in the basement flooding the entire food prep/storage area and the walk-in refrigerator. As per manager Tanner Berg, sewage backup started 1 day prior. Corrective action: Food service establishment was closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because the reason for sewage failure was not corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Sewage disposal system not provided, improperly constructed or not operating adequately in that grease trap was observed spewing with dirty oil and raw sewage in basement. The floor was observed flooded with approximately 4 - 6 inches deep of black, brown and gray waste liquid and was emitting a sewage odor throughout the basement area at the time of inspection. Corrective action: Operator instructed to contact a licensed plumber to fix the grease trap. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Sewage disposal system not provided, improperly constructed or not operating adequately in that liquid waste from hand wash sink observed draining onto the floor near the hand wash sink and a reach-down freezer in the front coffee prep area. The original metal waste line under said hand wash sink was observed disconnected and clear tubing was connected to the bottom of the hand wash sink basin. Said tubing was observed connected to a pump used for the coffee machine. Liquid waste water was observed overflowing from said pump and flooding onto the floor when using said sink. No other hand wash sinks were observed in the front coffee prep area. Corrective action: Said hand wash sink was closed off from use with tape and a sign. A hand wash sink was observed in the kitchen, which was measured less than 25 feet away from the coffee prep area, but was observed obstructed by a door. The manager removed door to kitchen and manager instructed food workers must wash hands in kitchen hand wash s

Sewage disposal system not provided, improperly constructed or not operating adequately in that liquid waste water was  observed back up from sewage line and flooded floor under dry food storage shelf and ice machine in  basement, during inspection. Operator was instructed to call plumber. Plumber came and fixed that sewage line, at end of inspection. Corrective action: Reason for sewage failure was corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Sewage/liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system in that waste observed contaminating area frequented by employees. The whole area in front basement was observed flooded with water of unknown origin. Foodworkers were observed crossing said flooded area to get to their changing area and to use employee restroom in basement. No food was observed being stored/prepared in said area. No smell of sewage observed. As per operator, unknown pipe broke and leaked said water, whichwas observed covering area 6'x12' and 2-3'' deep. Operator was observed using portable pump to remove said leak. Corrective action: No new incoming water was observed. Reason for sewage failure was corrected.  Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Toilet facilities not provided for employees in that out of order in the employee restroom. Toilet was observed over flooded and would not flush. Corrective action: Food service establishment was closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. NYCHC 81.22(a)

Flooring improperly constructed or maintained in that the concrete floor observed wet with small accumulations of standing water throughout all areas of the basement. Flooring improperly constructed or maintained in that tiled floor observed covered with absorbent cardboard in front of deep fryer in kitchen. 15 Dead roaches observed on cement floor in the following areas: 6 in flood storage area and 9 in gas hot water heater room in basement. Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that liquid waste (brown and greasy) from grease trap was observed contaminating food prep area in basement. Said liquid waste (approximately 8 inches in length and 3 inches in depth) was observed on floor in meter room at the time of inspection. As per manager, said food prep area was flooded one day prior. An employee was observed mopping said contaminated area at the time of inspection.Water marks were observed on food items that were stored directly on floor in basement food prep area at the time of inspection. Corrective action: All food was removed from the area.  Contaminated food was rendered inedible and discarded.  Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that white, cloudy water from the sewage line was observed contaminating the basement.  The white cloudy water was observed underneath wood panel flooring in the basement, where tables and beverages are stored.  The water also was observed coming from a sewage flood pit that contained approximately 2 feet of pink, gray and white sewage water with items floating inside of pool.  When food worker went upstairs to flush the toilet from the mens room, a surge of sewage water surged toward the reach-down and walk-in freezers. Corrective action: Food service establishment closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because sewage-contaminated area could not be properly cleaned. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food found contaminated in that 2 large raw oysters on the half shell observed to be contaminated by murky condensate water in that said food was being stored directly on base panel of 3 door lowboy refrigerator flooded with dirty, murky condensate water in 3-door lowboy refrigerator in rear prep area. Corrective action: Food was rendered inedible and discarded by food worker. NYCHC 81.07(a)

Food found contaminated in that 4 cases of assorted Snapple beverages on metal storage shelf, two containers with cooked tomato sauce stored directly on floor in walk-in refrigerator, a  carton of lettuce in walk-in refrigerator, a 40 pound box of raw chicken wings on a rolling cart in walk-in refrigerator were all observed to be contaminated by contact with liquid waste murky water that  flooded  entire basement food storage area. Corrective action: Foods were rendered inedible and discarded by food worker. NYCHC 81.07(a)

Food not protected at all times from potential sources of contamination in that approximately 20 pounds of cooked noodles in water in a plastic container was observed stored directly on flooded floor next to 2-compartment sink in basement food prep/storage area. NYCHC 81.07(d)

Food not protected at all times from potential sources of contamination in that TWO   chest deep freezer with frozen foods(assorted seafood and vegetables) observed stored directly on cement floor in basement.Said area is susceptible to flooding during heavy rainfall.

Food preparation area, food storage area or other area used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that brown colored liquid waste (approximately 3 feet radius X 1 inch depth) leaking from a sink and a separate 2-compartment sink (observed used for warewashing) was observed contaminating floor next to employee restroom in kitchen. Said area was flooded 3 days prior to inspection, as per FPC holder Jobeth Regalado's statement. Contaminating water marks (by footsteps) observed all over the kitchen ware washing area, walk-in refrigerator, and food prep area that clearly contaminating the FSE. Corrective action: Reason for the leaking was corrected. Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food preparation area, food storage area or other area used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that liquid sewage water leaking profusely from the ceiling above the delivery staircase leading to the outside was observed contaminating the food storage area in the basement. liquid waste was observed flooding the floor of the food/paper goods storage area containing single use items for customer use and an assortment of condiments. Walk-in refrigerator is also located in the basement approximately 20 feet away from where the leakage is occurring. Corrective action: Operator closed down the FSE and called a licensed plumber. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Handwash facility inadequate in that front food  prep area, kitchen food prep area and employees' unisex restroom hand wash sink observed without hot and cold running water, during inspection. The main water supply was pulled out by operator which resulted to excessive flooding inside FSE and main water supply valve was shut off by operator. NYCHC 81.21(b)

Hand washing sink obstructed in or near ground floor kitchen. Only handwash sink in kitchen is obstructed from use by two kitchen workers by a permanently stationed employee who operates the diswasher, preventing workers from reasonably accessing the only available handwash sink.  Employee who operates the dshwasher must exit the kitchen through a door between the warewashing and food prep area for the workers in the kitchen to access said sink. Additionally, the sink was malfunctioning and causing the floor of the kitchen to flood at time of inspection, indicating that the sink was not in regular use by the food workers. The nearest handwash sink is behind the front service area, obstructed from the kitchen by  door and accessed through the dining area Corrective action: Operator was instructed that employee operating dishwasher must not obstruct handwash sink while active food prep occurs in said area. NYCHC 81.21(a)

Sewage disposal system not provided, improperly constructed or not operating adequately in that sewage backup observed in basement at time of inspection. 3 rooms in basement were observed flooded with approximately 1" of water and 2 rooms were observed with food area and food storage area. One room observed with a hand wash sink, 3-compartment sink and a food prep table and walk-in refrgierator was located in said room. No water observed inside walk-in refrigerator as the door was airtight and some carpet and plastic bags were placed at the bottom of the door. Another room observed with 3 reach-in freezers which were about 4" higher than water level. Another in front observed with no storage. Main drain located in food storage room was oberved uncovered and waste water came out from said drain, as per operator. Water was not coming out at time of inspection. Operator found out the incident when he opened FSE 3 hours earlier. Plumber and landlord were contacted, but no informa

Sewage disposal system not provided, improperly constructed or not operating adequately in that stagnant cloudy liquid waste water due to sewage back up from floor drain basement non-food storage area observed measuring approximately 1 inch deep in the tiled floor of the basement main area where old equipment is stored and the concrete floor of the garbage storage area of basement. Basement was flooded from sewage back up coming from the drain in the middle of the main area of the basement 1 hour prior to inspection, as per operator's statement. Corrective action: Food service establishment was closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because the reason for sewage failure was not corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Sewage/liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system in that waste observed contaminating beneath 3-compartment sink and handwash sink in kitchen. Grease trap noted clogged and wasteline and grease trap noted leaking water onto floor at time of inspection. Waste water with grease noted on floor behind 1 door reach-in refrigerator in front food prep area. FSE unable to use handwash sink in kitchen or 3-compartment sink due to clogged pipes. Hot water noted turned off at all sinks at time of inspection. Hot water is turned off in order to prevent flooding of area, as per operator. Corrective action: Food service establishment closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because reason for sewage failure was not corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Walls, ceilings and their attached fixtures not properly constructed or maintained in that ceiling was observed with multiple holes in the following areas:  2 holes (approximately 2-3'' in diameter) was observed around metal pipes in compressor closet on second floor, 1 hole approximately 2'' in diameter was observed around metal pipe in electrical box closet in storage area on second flood, 1 hole (approximately 3'' in diameter) observed above reach down freezer chest in storage room on second floor, and 1 hole (approximately 2'' in diameter)  was observed around metal pipe above stairwell leading from first floor to second floor. NYCHC 81.17( e) (2)

Cross-connection in the potable water supply system observed in that a gooseneck hose was extending down and reaching the bottom of the middle sink of a 3-compartment sink at the kitchen. The gooseneck hose was observed connected to a faucet which was connected to a potable water line. No backflow prevention device was observed on the potable water line connected to the gooseneck hose. The middle sink was observed with stagnant water and dishes and cooking pans with old food residue. Corrective action: Cross connection was disconnected by removing the gooseneck hose out of the sink and placed above the flood level of the sink restoring the air gap. NYCHC 81.20(a)

Displayed food not protected at all times from potential sources of contamination in that approximately 6 ounces of  ready-to-eat croutons  observed on display without protective covering on  soup display shelf  in customer self service buffet area in 2nd flood customer self service area. NYCHC 81.07(e)

Evidence of mouse activity present in that 33 fresh mice excreta observed in the following areas: 4 observed on floor next to 1-door reach-in refrigerator in 2nd floor, 2 observed along floor wall junction outside liquor storage room in 2nd floor, 23 observed on flood under liquor storage shelf in 2nd floor and 2 observed on wooden ledge in bar and 2 observed on floor in bar. Corrective action: Operator instructed to implement proper pest control measures by removing harborage conditions, such as standing water, closing all entry ways and holes, storing food in vermin proof containers, eliminating breeding conditions, improve overall sanitary conditions, and provide proper extermination, if necessary.  All contaminated area and equipment are to be washed, rinsed, and sanitized.NYCHC 81.23(a)

Evidence of mouse activity present in that 387 fresh mice excreta observed in the following locations: 172 observed along the wall and flood junction under 3-compartment sink in the basement kitchen, 157 observed along the wall and floor junction behind electrical ovens in the kitchen, 22 observed along the wall and floor junction under metal prep table in the basement kitchen, 25 observed on the floor behind black metal food storage/paper goods storage shelf in the basement kitchen, and 11 observed on the wall ledge next to basement stairway in the basement kitchen. Corrective action: Establishment ordered closed by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene due to severe mouse infestation.NYCHC 81.23(a)

Facility conditions conducive to the existence of pest life observed in that 1 hole approximately 2 inches in diameter observed around pipe leading into ceiling in basement and 1 hole appoximately 3 inches in diameter obseved in mesh that is used to cover metal flood gate that has holes approximately 2 inches in diameters leading to outside in basement. NYCHC 81.23(a)

Facility conditions conducive to the existence of pest life observed in that large areas of the floor of the establishment were observed flooded & exit door wsa observed open & without flies screen  in in cart storage area. NYCHC 81.23(a)

Facility conditions conducive to the existence of pest life observed in that open rear door which was leading to backyard, observed in kitchen. Old food particles observed at the opening of pipe which comes from wok stove and in funnel below said pipe in kitchen. Old flood particles observed in funnel under 3-compartment sink in kitchen.. NYCHC 81.23(a)

Facility conditions conducive to the existence of pest life observed in that tiled floor observed with standing water under and near 3-compartment sink and dishwasher in basement. Grease and old flood particles observed on table under gyro machines in front food prep/ service area. NYCHC 81.23(a)
Flooring improperly constructed or maintained in that cement/concrete floor observed flooded with beer in the walk-in keg refrigerator in the sub-basement. NYCHC 81.17(e) (1)
Flooring improperly constructed or maintained in that cement/concrete floor observed heavily flooded and littered with moist decaying organic matters in rear cart storage room. NYCHC 81.17(e)(1)
Flooring improperly constructed or maintained in that main bowl cart storage area, walk-in-refrigerator and food prep area / administrative desk triage floor observed everely flooded . NYCHC 81.21(e)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid in that approximately 1/2 inch of sewage water was observed contaminating basement food storage area and dishwashing area in basement. Plumber onsite upon begining of inspection stating that pipe had burst due to cold weather and drain was clogged. Was observed running water from 3 compartment sink and water was running back onto floor from floor drain. Food was being prepared on main floor while basement had flood issue. Establishment opened at 5pm as per operator and flooding issue was noted day previous. Corrective action: Reason for sewage failure was corrected.  Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. All food located in basement discarded. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that approximately 2 inches of dark murky standing sewage waste water with floating debris, and a pungent odor  was observed contaminating the basement dry goods, canned goods, and  equipment storage area. The food workers have to step through the sewage waste water to access the dry goods, and canned goods storage area in the basement. As per operator the basement has been flooded with the waste water 24 hours ( a day prior )  to inspection . Corrective action: All food was removed from the area.  Contaminated food was rendered inedible and discarded.  Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that liquid waste  was observed contaminating kitchen & rear storage area. At the time of inspection liquid waste was backing up from the drain pipe under the steamers & flooding the kitchen & rear storage area. Said liquid waste was flowing constantly for approximately 10 minutes until the house tra unclog to release the liquid waste. Corrective action: Reason for sewage failure was corrected.  Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that murky water (measuring approximately 10 feet in diameter) emitting a foul odor was observed contaminating hookah preparation area. Said sewage observed coming from floor-wall junction at time of inspection. Hookah prepatation equipment, beer bottles and a reach-in freezer containing food was observed in said area. As per manager ''Hemrani Kalicharan statement, basement area was flooded with said sewage 2 hours prior to inspection but did not know where it was coming from. (1) male employee observed preparing hookah in observed sewage area at time of inspection. Corrective action: All food was removed from the area.  Contaminated food was rendered inedible and discarded.  Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that sewage from clogged floor drain was observed contaminating basement hallway leading to food/equipment storage room. Putrid smell was observed emanating from water. Workers must pass through flooded area in order to reach supplies in food/equipment storage room. One food worker was observed crossing wooden planks in flooded area at time of inspection. Corrective action: Plumber removed clog in floor drain correcting sewage failure.  Contaminated area was washed, rinsed and sanitized with bleach and water by building plumber. Paper goods and supplies were relocated to 1st floor storage area. All food in food/equipment storage room was voluntarily discarded. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food not protected at all times from potential sources of contamination in that 1 cardboard box (approximately 5 pounds) of Blue moon beer, and 1 cardboard box (approximately 5 pounds) of Sweet Amigo Sangria wine were observed stored directly on dirty floor in front storage area in basement. Said boxes were observed with watermarks from liquid waste flooding at the time of inspection. NYCHC 81.07(d)

Handwash facility inadequate in that kitchen and front service prep area hand wash sink observed without, hot running water. Hot water heater located in basement of next door Chinese restaurant was turned off, due to a flood caused by a leaking water pipe. Said heater was turned back on by the superintendent, and hot water was restored. NYCHC 81.29(c)

Harborage or conditions conducive to rodents, insects or other pests exist in that an accumulation of dried-up old food particles and debris was observed on floor under 3-compartment sink in dish-washing area and on floor in dry food storage area under stairway leading to 2nd flood.. NYCHC 81.23(a) Please note that the violation you have been issued for having conditions conducive the existence of pests is separate and distinct from the violation you have been issued for having pests and both may be sustained by the Hearings Division. See DOHMH v. Harissa LLC, Dkt 0879213F0, Appeal Decision Oct. 8, 2013 at 1 and DOHMH v. Just Lorraine's Place, LLC Dkt 2748012F1, Appeal Decision Apr. 9, 2013 at 4. available on nyls.edu/cityadmin.

No facilities to wash, rinse and sanitize equipment, utensils and tableware provided in that 3-compartment sink not available for ware washing operation. observed with broken pipe and one compartment clogging making warewashing impossible and causing heavy flooding  in the kitchen. . NYCHC 81.29(a)

Sewage and liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system so as to prevent contamination of the premises and its contents in that cooling systems pipeline was observed broken creating a leak that caused flooding in the basement of the establishment. Sewage/liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system in that waste observed contaminating kitchen floor from an overflowing drain under dishwasher (waste water observed white and with debris no odor detected) said water drained down to basement creating a flood approximately 2 inches high in the area of hot water heater. Sewage/liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system in that waste observed contaminating kitchen/food prep  area frequented by employees, at time of inspection. Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that an accumulation of liquid waste approximately 2 inches deep was observed contaminating the entire food and supply storage area in the basement. Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that liquid waste backed up from floor drain was observed contaminating garbage/cleaning supply storage room in basement storage area. Garbage/cleaning supply storage room is actively accessed by employees. Corrective action: Operator instructed to contact plumber followed by washing, rinsing and sanitizing contaminated area. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that liquid waste was observed contaminating the basement where food storage, food preparation, and warewashing was observed. Food, food preparation area, food storage area or area(s) used by employees or patrons contaminated by sewage or liquid waste in that the rear food prep area in basement was observed contaminated by brown and greasy waste water that was flowing directly from clogged grease trap in grease trap room directly into said prep area. Sewage disposal system not provided, improperly constructed or not operating adequately in that liquid waste observed back-flowing from broken sump pump and causing flooding in the electric water heater room in the basement. Said backed-up waste water observed not reaching food storage area at time of inspection. Corrective action: Reason for sewage failure was corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Sewage disposal system not provided, improperly constructed or not operating adequately in that liquid waste observed on floor in storage room and prep areas in the basement.  Storage room with packs of beer and hot water heater observed with flooding water approximately 4 inches deep in the basmeent. Food prep/storage room observed with flooding water approximately 1 inch thick in the basement. As per operator establisment was observed with flooding from ceiling gaps the evening prior to inspection. Corrective action: Food service establishment was closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because the reason for sewage failure was not corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Sewage/liquid waste not carried to sewer or sewage disposal system in that waste observed contaminating basement food storage area. Water approximately five inches high noted  on floor throughout basement and in walk-in refrigerator in basement . As per  Daniel Armstrong maintenance worker there was plumbing work being done on drains yesterday and a 12 inch pipe was not closed therefore the water that was supposed to flow into the street backed up into the basement and caused the flood. Also the furniture store next door was flooded due to a backed up drain and this water also flooded the basement. Corrective action: Food service establishment closed by Order of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene because reason for sewage failure was not corrected. NYCHC 81.20(b)

Toilet facilities not provided for employees in that both of the establishment's only two restrooms were observed out of order due to establishment's sewage problem. As per operator, if toilet is flushed it will cause more sewage waste to flood the basement. Corrective action: Plumber stopped the sewage backup at time of inspection, thereby allowing full use of the toilet facilities by employees and patrons. NYCHC 81.29(a)

Walls, ceilings and their attached fixtures not properly constructed or maintained in that painted ceiling was observed with large (approximately 3''x20'' in size) holes and hanging paint inside the employee-only restroom in basement. As per interview, said holes formed due to flooding from sidewalks during rains. NYCHC 81.17( e) (2)
